DISCLAIMER
   The Codified Ordinances and other documents that appear in this FOLIO Infobase
may not reflect the most current legislation adopted by the Municipality.  The
Codified Ordinances are provided for informational purposes only and should not be
relied upon as the definitive authority for local legislation.  Additionally, the
formatting and pagination of the posted documents vary from the formatting and
pagination of the official copy.  The official printed copy of the Codified
Ordinances should be consulted prior to any action being taken. 
   For further information regarding the official version of any portion of the
Codified Ordinances in this FOLIO Infobase, please contact the Municipality
directly.

   We, William "Doug" Franklin, Mayor, and Brenda Smith, Council Clerk, of the
City of Warren, Ohio, pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.23 and 731.42, hereby certify
that the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Warren, Ohio, as
revised, rearranged, compiled, renumbered as to sections, recodified and
printed herewith in component codes are correctly set forth and constitute the
Codified Ordinances of the City of Warren, Ohio, 1978, as amended to September
12, 2018.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE
REQUESTED BY:    LAW DEPARTMENT
TALANCA    DRAFT NO. 3 724
TITLE
AN ORDINANCE TO APPROVE, ADOPT AND ENACT THE 1979 CODIFIED ORDINANCES; TO
REPEAL ORDINANCES IN CONFLICT THEREWITH; TO PUBLISH THE ENACTMENT OF NEW
MATTER; AND DECLARING AN EMERGENCY
ORDINANCE NO. 8875/80
   WHEREAS, the present general and permanent ordinances of the City of Warren,
are inadequately arranged and classified and are insufficient in form and
substance for the complete preservation of the public peace, property, health,
safety and welfare of the City and for the proper conduct of its affairs; and
   WHEREAS, Council has heretofore entered into a contract with the Walter H.
Drane Company to prepare and publish such recodification, and
   WHEREAS, the recodification of such ordinances, together with the new matter
to be adopted, the matters to be amended and those to be repealed are before
Council.
   BE IT ORDAINED by the Council of the City of Warren, State of Ohio:
   Section 1: That the ordinances of the City of Warren, Ohio, of a general and
permanent nature, as revised, recodified, rearranged and consolidated into
component codes, titles, chapters and sections are hereby approved, adopted and
enacted as the Codified Ordinances of the City of Warren, Ohio, 1979.
   One book-form copy of the Codified Ordinances shall be certified as correct
by the Mayor and the Clerk of Council, attached to this Ordinance as a part
hereof, and filed with the permanent ordinance records of the City.
   Section 2: That the provisions of this Ordinance, including all provisions
of the Codified Ordinances, shall be in full force and effect as provided in
Section 4 of this Ordinance. All Ordinances and resolutions or parts thereof
enacted prior to October 22, 1978, which are inconsistent with any provision of
the Codified Ordinances, are hereby repealed as of the effective date of this
Ordinance, except as follows:
(a)    The enactment of the Codified Ordinances shall not be construed to
affect a right or liability accrued or incurred under any legislative
provisions prior to the effective date of such enactment, or an action or
proceeding for the enforcement of such right or liability. Such enactment shall
not be construed to relieve any person from punishment for an act committed in
violation of any such legislative provision, nor to affect an indictment or
prosecution therefor. For such purposes, any such legislative provision shall
continue in full force notwithstanding its repeal for the purpose of revision
and recodification.
(b)    The repeal provided above shall not affect:
(1)    The grant or creation of a franchise, license, right, easement or
privilege.
(2)    The purchase, sale, lease or transfer of property.
(3)    The appropriation or expenditure of money or promise or guarantee of
payment.
(4)    The assumption of any contract or obligation.
(5)    The issuance and delivery of any bonds, obligations or other instruments
of indebtedness.
(6)    The levy of imposition of taxes, assessments or charges.
(7)    The establishment, naming, vacation or grade level of any street or
public way.
(8)   The dedication of property or plat approval.
(9)    The annexation or detachment of territory.
(10)    Any legislation enacted subsequent to October 22, 1978.
   Section 3: That the Clerk of Council pursuant to Ohio R.C. 731.21 and 731.23
shall cause to be published in the manner required by law a summary of new
matter contained in the Codified Ordinances. Each section of the 1979 Codified
Ordinances without a previous ordinance or resolution history, or containing a
subsection with the words "Adopting Ordinance", at the end thereof indicates
that the section contains new matter ordained by this Adopting Ordinance.
   Section 4: That this Ordinance is hereby declared to be an emergency measure
necessary for the immediate preservation of the public peace, health and
welfare, and for the further reason that there exists an imperative necessity
for the earliest publication and distribution of the Codified Ordinances to the
officials and residents of the City, so as to facilitate the administration and
daily operation of the City and avoid practical and legal entanglements;
   WHEREFORE, this Ordinance shall take effect and be in force after its
passage and approval by the Mayor.
 
   Passed in Council this 13th  day of February, 1980.

EDITOR'S NOTE
   The arrangement and numbering of the Codified Ordinances into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections are based on an adaptation of the decimal
numbering system which is similar to that used in the Ohio Revised Code, and in
accord with the best accepted practice in instituting a codification. Each
section is self-identifying as to code, chapter and section number. For
example, 305.06 indicates that the code number is 3, the chapter number is 305
(or the 5th chapter within code 3), and the section number is .06. The code and
chapter numbers appear left of the decimal, with the code number preceding the
first two digits left of the decimal, and the chapter number being all digits
left of the decimal. The section number appears right of the decimal. As
another example, 113.10 indicates the code number is 1, the chapter number is
113 (or the 13th chapter within code 1), and the section number is .10.
   This numbering system has the advantage of inherent flexibility in allowing
for an almost endless amount of expansion. Codes, titles and chapters initially
are odd-numbered, thus reserving the use of even numbers for future
legislation. Sections within chapters are consecutively numbered, except that
penalty provisions are usually assigned the number .99 as used in the Revised
Code. Newly created sections subsequent to the original codification may be
indicated by three digits right of the decimal in the event the law properly
belongs between two consecutively numbered sections. For example, newly created
575.061, 575.062 and 575.063 follow 575.06 and precede 575.07 to be placed in
their logical position.
   Section histories enable a user to trace the origin of the law contained in
the section. The history indicates the derivation by reference to either its
passage date and the ordinance number originally assigned to it at that time,
or to its inclusion in any prior code. Sections without histories indicate that
the section contains new matter which was ordained by the Adopting Ordinance
which enacts the Codified Ordinances.
   The Comparative Section Table is included to show the disposition of every
ordinance included in the Codified Ordinances. It indicates whether a given
ordinance was consolidated with another into one section or split into two or
more sections. Cross references direct the user to subject matter reasonably
related to material contained within a given chapter.

Codified Ordinances

CROSS REFERENCES

   101.01  DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)    All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Warren, Ohio, 1978, for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(O.R.C. 1.01)
   (b)    All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01 ".
   101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
(a)    "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it.
(ORC 1.02 (F))
(b)    "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
   (O.R.C. 1.02 (B))
(c)    "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
   (O.R.C. 1.02 (D), (E))
(d)    "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
(e)    "County" means Trumbull County, Ohio.
(f)    "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
(g)    "Land" or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an incorporeal
nature.
(ORC 701.01(F))
(h)    "Municipality" or "City" means the City of Warren, Ohio.
(i)    "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm.
    (O.R.C. 1.59(B))
(j)    "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner
or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
(k)    "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
   (O.R.C. 1.59 (C))
(l)    "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
(m)    "Property" means real and personal property.
   (O.R.C. 1.59(E))
   "Personal property" includes all property except real. "Real property"
includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
(n)    "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal, County,
State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof, or any duly
authorized public official.
(o)    "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
(p)    "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail" includes
registered mail.
   (O.R.C. 1.02 (G))
(q)    "Rule" includes regulation.
   (O.R.C. 1.59(F))
(r)    "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
(s)    "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio.
    (ORC 1.59(G))
(t)    "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads, highways,
viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
(u)    "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
(v)    "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents and employees; and all officials, public or private.
   (O.R.C. 1.02(A))
(w)    "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words, letters,
symbols  or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating to
signatures.
   (O.R.C. 1.59(J))
(x)    "Regular employee" means an employee who works not less than thirty
hours per week.
   101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)    Common and Technical Usage. Words and phrases shall be read in
context and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words
and phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(O.R.C. 1.42)
   (b)    Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
(1)    The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the singular.
(2)    Words of one gender include the other genders.
(3)    Words in the present tense include the future.
         (O.R.C. 1.43)
   (c)    Calendar; Computation of Time.
(1)    Definitions.
A.    "Week" means seven consecutive days.
B.    "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
   (O.R.C. 1.44)
(2)    If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months from a
particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the concluding
month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun, unless there
are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the period ends
on the last day of that month.
   (O.R.C. 1.45)
(3)    The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall be
computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. When a public
office, in which an act required by law is to be performed, is closed to the
public for the entire day which constitutes the last day for doing such act or
before its usual closing time on such day, then such act may be performed on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. If any legal
holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
   (O.R.C. 1.14)
(4)    When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and after a
day named, no part of that day shall be included.
   (O.R.C. 1.15)
(5)    In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice. 
   (d)    Authority. When the law requires an act to be done which may by law
as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)    Joint Authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to
three or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving
such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall
be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)    Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law
which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when
the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
   101.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)    The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(O.R.C. 1.57)
   (b)    An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(O.R.C. 1.54)
   (c)    The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not,
except as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
(1)    Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action taken
thereunder;
(2)    Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or liability
previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
(3)    Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
(4)    Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any such
privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and the
investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or enforced,
and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the ordinance had not
been repealed or amended.
   (d)    If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a re-enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(O.R.C. 1.58)
   101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)    A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
re-enactments or amendments thereof.
(O.R.C. 1.55)
   (b)    If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(O.R.C. 1.56)
   (c)    Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(O.R.C. 1.23)
   101.06  CONFLICTING PROVISIONS
   (a)    If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(O.R.C. 1.46)
   (b)    If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(O.R.C. 1.51)
(c)    (1)    If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
(2)    If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different meetings of
Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments are to be
harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each. If the amendments
are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment prevails. The
fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an earlier amendment,
or fails to include language inserted by an earlier amendment, does not of
itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments are irreconcilable only
when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into simultaneous operation.
         (O.R.C. 1.52)
   101.07  DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)    In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
(1)    Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United States
is intended;
(2)    The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
(3)    A just and reasonable result is intended;
(4)    A result feasible of execution is intended.
   (O.R.C. 1.47)
   (b)    An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(O.R.C. 1.48)
   (c)    If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
(1)    The object sought to be attained;
(2)    The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
(3)    The legislative history; 
(4)    The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws upon the
same or similar subjects;
(5)    The consequences of a particular construction;
(6)    The administrative construction of the ordinance.
   (O.R.C. 1.49)
   101.08  SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(O.R.C. 1.50)
   101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00), or imprisoned not more than
six months, or both. A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day
during or on which a violation continues or occurs.
CHAPTER 103
Official Standards
103.01   Official time.
103.02   City seal.
103.03   Display of State flag.
CROSS REFERENCES
State standard of time - see Ohio R.C. 1.04
State legal holidays - see Ohio R.C. 1.14, 5.20 et seq.
   103.01  OFFICIAL TIME.
   All City offices and legal and official proceedings under the control of the
City shall be determined and regulated by the official standard of time in
effect throughout the State, and when by ordinance, resolution or action of
Council, or action of any City officer, board or body, an act must be performed
at or within a prescribed time, it shall be so performed according to such
standard of time. All clocks maintained in or upon all public buildings in and
under the custody and control of the City shall be set and run according to the
provisions of this section.
(Ord. 4491/53. Passed 10-19-53. )
   103.02  CITY SEAL.
   (a)    The seal, designed for the City by William P. McLain, Director of
Law, which depicts a map of the State of Ohio within a circle depicted by an
industrial gear to denote the modern pre-eminence of the City as an industrial
center and locates the City by the placement of a replica of the first log
cabin school house in Warren, is hereby approved and adopted as the official
seal of the City.
   (b)    The Director of Public Service and Safety shall cause to be prepared
an impression of the seal for use on the official documents of the City.
(Ord. 7468/72. Passed 6-5-72. )
[https://export.amlegal.com/media/d9bcc23676fa2375932495580a09c8462a6564ac/
IMAGES/0-0-0-161.jpg]
   (c)    By December l, 1995, except for investigative and undercover motor
vehicles operated by the Police Department or Fire Department of the City, also
vehicles in the Court that handle capias, warrants and official documents of
the Court, each motor vehicle of the City, or operated by the City, shall be
marked, in a conspicuous manner, on the outside at all times with the seal as
depicted within this section.
(Ord. 10825/95. Passed 10/25/95.)
   103.03  DISPLAY OF STATE FLAG.
   (a)    The official flag of the State of Ohio shall be flown at all places
where the flag of the United States is presently flown. The flag of Ohio shall
be flown directly under the flag of the United States and on flagstaffs
maintained by the City.
   (b)    The American Legion, V.F.W, and D.A.V. shall participate in this
program by the donation of the State flag and incorporate the same by
appropriate ceremonies.
(Ord. 8957/80. Passed 10-8-80.)
CHAPTER 105
Wards and Boundaries
105.01   Establishment; number.
105.02   First Ward.
105.03   Second Ward.
105.04   Third Ward.
105.05   Fourth Ward.
105.06   Fifth Ward.

CROSS REFERENCES
         Division into wards - see Ohio R.C. 731.06
         Voting precincts - see Ohio R.C. 3501.18
   105.01  ESTABLISHMENT; NUMBER.
   The City is subdivided into seven wards, which are equal in number to the
members of Council who are hereafter to be elected from wards according to
law.  Such seven wards are established in this City, and the boundaries thereof
shall be such as are hereinafter set forth, which boundaries are fixed so that
each ward shall contain as nearly as practicable an equal number of
inhabitants.
(Ord. 10328/91.  Passed 12-11-91.)
   105.02  FIRST WARD.
   The First Ward shall contain all that territory bounded and described as
follows:
   Beginning at a point where the centerline of the Mahoning River intersects
the centerline of South Street, S.W.; thence westerly along the centerline of
South Street, S.W. to the centerline of West Market Street; thence continuing
westerly along the centerline of West Market Street to a point where the
centerline of Parkman Road, N.W. if extended southerly would intersect; thence
northerly along the extended centerline of Parkman Road, N.W. and continuing
northerly and northwesterly along the centerline of Parkman Road, N.W. to a
point in the westerly corner of a 3.444 acre parcel of land, such point also
being in the 1981 corporation line as established by Ordinance 9023/81, dated
March 25, 1981; thence northeasterly, easterly and southwesterly along the 1981
corporation line to a point in the centerline of Parkman Road, N.W.; thence
southeasterly along the centerline of Parkman Road, N.W. to a point in the 1983
corporation line as established by  Ordinance 9360/83, dated September 30,
1983; thence northeasterly and southeasterly along the 1983 corporation line to
a point in the centerline of North Leavitt Road, N.W.; thence northerly along
the centerline of North Leavitt Road, N.W. and the 1979 corporation line, as
established by Ordinance 8800/79, dated September 10, 1979, to a point where
the centerline of North River Road if extended southwesterly would intersect;
thence northeasterly along the extended centerline and centerline of North
River Road and the 1979 corporation line to a point being the northerlymost
corner of the 1979 corporation line; thence east-south-east along the 1979
corporation line to a point in the centerline of the Mahoning River; thence
northerly and easterly along the corporation line and centerline of the
Mahoning River to a point; thence southerly along the corporation line to a
point in the south street line of Tod Avenue, N.W.; thence easterly along the
corporation line and the south street line of Tod Avenue, N.W. to a point;
thence northerly along the corporation line to the centerline of the Mahoning
River; thence northerly, easterly and southerly and along the centerline of the
Mahoning River following its various courses to a point in the centerline of
South Street, S.W. which is the true point of beginning.
(Ord. 10328/91.  Passed 12-11-91.)
   105.03  SECOND WARD.

line; thence easterly along the corporation line and across North Park Avenue
and along the north line of Ivanhoe Street, N.E. and its extension, to a point
in the east right-of-way line of the Conrail Railroad, formerly known as the
Penn-Central Railroad; thence southerly along the corporation line and the east
right-of-way line to a point in the north right-of-way of the Conrail Railroad,
formerly known as the Erie Lackawanna Railroad; thence northeasterly along the
north right-of-way line and the corporation line to a point in the north right-
of-way line of Yale Street, N.E.; thence easterly to a point where the

southwesterly along the centerline of Elm Road, N.E.; to a point where the
centerline of Atlantic Street, N.E. if extended easterly would intersect;
thence westerly along the extended centerline and the centerline of Atlantic
Street, N.E. to a point in the centerline of Paige Avenue, N.E.; thence
southerly along the centerline of Paige Avenue, N.E. to a point in the
centerline of Belmont Street, N.E.; thence westerly along the  centerline of
Belmont Street, N.E. to a point in the centerline of Vine Avenue, N.E.; thence
southerly along the centerline of Vine Avenue, N.E. to a point in the
centerline of Washington Street, N.E.; thence westerly along the centerline of
Washington Street N.E. to a point in the centerline of Mahoning Avenue, N.W.,
which is the true place of beginning.
(Ord. 10328/91.  Passed 12-11-91.)

northerly along the centerline of Lovers Lane, N.W. and the extended centerline
of Lovers Lane, N.W. and the corporation line to a point in the centerline of
the Mahoning River; thence continuing northerly along the centerline of the
Mahoning River and the corporation line to a point in the 1972 corporation line
as established by Ordinance 7455/72, dated June 6, 1972; thence westerly,
northerly and easterly along the 1972 corporation line to a point in the
centerline of the Mahoning River and the corporation line; thence northerly
following the corporation line along its various courses to a point in the
centerline of the Mahoning River, such point being the southeast corner of a
forty-two acre parcel of land annexed to the City by Ordinance 7254/71, dated
February 18, 1971; thence westerly following the 1971 corporation line along
its various courses to a point in the centerline of North Leavitt Road, N.W.;
thence northeasterly along the centerline of North Leavitt Road, N.W. and the
1971 corporation line to a point; thence westerly along the 1971 corporation
line to a point being in the west 1990 corporation line of the City being a
79.66 acre parcel of land annexed to the City by Ordinance 10060/89, dated
December 13, 1989; thence southerly, westerly and northerly along the 1990
corporation line and  following its various courses to the centerline of
Parkman Road, N.W.; thence southwesterly and southerly along the centerline of
Parkman Road, N.W. and its extension to a point in the centerline of West
Market Street, which is the true place of beginning.
(Ord. 10328/91. Passed 12-11-91.)
   105.09  INTENT; ANNEXATION.
   The intent of this chapter is to include of all the incorporated lands of
the City within the boundaries as set forth for the wards.
   Any land presently within the corporate limits of the City, not expressly
herein described or otherwise provided for within the boundaries of a ward
shall be part of the ward to which such land is immediately adjacent.
   Unincorporated land surrounded by the boundaries of the Municipal
Corporation are not intended to be included within the boundaries of a ward.
   Upon the legally effective date of annexation of territory to the City, such
territory shall become part of the ward to which the territory is immediately
adjacent, unless otherwise specifically provided for by Council by ordinance.
(Ord. 10328/91.  Passed 12-11-91.)
CHAPTER 107
Open Meetings
107.01   Meetings of public bodies.
107.02   Public notification.
107.03   Personal notification.
107.04   Minutes of meetings.
CROSS REFERENCE
Open meetings - see Ohio R. C. 121.22
   107.01  MEETINGS OF PUBLIC BODIES.
   Unless otherwise provided by law, all meetings of Council, Council
committees, commissions, boards, citizens' advisory committees, special
committees or any other similar decision-making body of the Municipal
government shall be conducted in open and public meetings.
   A meeting shall constitute any pre-arranged discussion of the public
business of such public body by a majority of its members.
   Nothing herein, however, shall be construed to mandate public participation
in such meetings unless specifically required by law or ordinance.
(Ord. 8263/75. Passed 12-8-75.)
   107.02  PUBLIC NOTIFICATION.
   (a)    Regular Meetings. The time, place and date of all regular meetings of
Municipal public bodies shall be noted in a calendar of monthly meetings to be
prepared and maintained by the Clerk of Council. The calendar shall be posted
in City Hall and the Municipal Justice Center and published in a newspaper of
general circulation at least five days prior to the first day of the month in
which the meetings are to be held.
   (b)    Special Meetings. Notification of any special meeting of any public
body shall be made to any news media requesting such notification twenty-four
hours prior to the time of such meeting.
   (c)    Emergency Meetings. Notice of any emergency meeting shall be
communicated to the news media that have requested notification of the time,
place and purpose of the emergency meeting.
(Ord. 8263/75. Passed 12-8-75.)
   107.03  PERSONAL NOTIFICATION.
   (a)    Any person, organization or group wishing a notice of the monthly
meetings shall request the same in writing of the Clerk of Council, on forms
provided, and shall furnish a stamped, self-addressed envelope for such
purpose.
   (b)    Any person, organization or group requesting advance notice of
meetings at which any specific type of business shall be conducted or
discussed, may obtain notice by requesting the same from the Clerk of Council
on forms provided, and shall furnish a stamped, self-addressed envelope.
(Ord. 8263/75. Passed 12-8-75.)
   107.04  MINUTES OF MEETINGS.
   The minutes of all regular and special meetings of all public bodies shall
be promptly recorded and open to the public for inspection.
   The minutes of executive sessions, as authorized by law, need only reflect
the general subject matter or discussion.
(Ord. 8263/75. Passed 12-8-75.)

107
         Meetings - see Ohio R.C. 731.44, 731.46

         Qualifications - see Ohio R.C. 731.02, 731.44

   111.01  MEETINGS.
   Council shall meet on the second and fourth Wednesdays of each month at 7:30
p.m. at the Council chambers.  In the event a regular meeting night falls on a
legal holiday, such meeting shall be carried over to the following day.  The
Mayor or any three members of Council may call special meetings upon at least
twelve hours’ notice to each member, served personally or left at his usual
place of residence.
   111.02  CLERK OF COUNCIL; DUTIES.
   Council is authorized to employ a Clerk and Deputy Clerk of Council.  The
Clerk of Council shall be required to attend all regular and special meetings
of Council, keep proper files of all papers and documents which are a part of
the transactions of Council, and make such records available to the public.
   The Clerk shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by Council.
(Ord. 10454/92.  Passed 11-24-92.)
   111.021 FURNISHING LEGISLATION TO LIBRARY.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council is hereby authorized and directed to provide the
Warren Public Library with copies of all legislation passed by Council,
together with the summary of each meeting.
   (b)   The various departments of the City making annual reports, shall
include one for Clerk of Council for delivery to the Warren Public Library.
(Ord. 8743/79.  Passed 4-23-79.)
   111.022 SALE OF CODIFIED ORDINANCES.
   (a)   The Clerk of Council shall be the official custodian of the
uncirculated copies of the Codified Ordinances and shall keep the same updated
from time to time with any additions or supplements.  (Ord. 11363/99.  Passed
12-22-99.)
   (b)   The Clerk shall charge for the following documents as follows:
 
Codified Ordinances (complete set)                              $125.00
General Offenses Code binder                                      15.00
Traffic Code binder                                               15.00
Building Code binder                                              15.00
Zoning Code binder                                                15.00
Codified Ordinances yearly supplements                            25.00
All other copies from the Codified Ordinances, minutes or other 05¢ per page
public documents
   All fees collected in the administration of this section shall be deposited
to the credit of the General Fund, Miscellaneous Sales.
(Ord.  11769/04.  Passed 4-28-04.)
   111.03  CITIZENS’ ADVISORY COMMITTEE ON ENERGY AND UTILITIES.
   (a)   There is hereby created a Citizens’ Advisory Committee on Energy and
Utilities to serve the Public Utilities Committee of Council by providing
advice, information and concerns of the residents of the City with regard to
energy and public utility matters.
   (b)   The Advisory Committee shall serve the Public Utilities Committee of
Council and shall be composed of five members appointed for each term of
Council and the appointments to its organization meetings and work shall be
determined and directed by the Public Utilities Committee and the Advisory
Committee shall be responsible to and report to the Public Utilities Committee.
   (c)   The President of Council is authorized to make available
administrative space to assist the Advisory Committee in its work under such
direction as is given by the Public Utilities Committee from time to time.
(Ord. 9742/87.  Passed 1-14-87.)
   111.04  REPORTS TO COUNCIL; COPIES.
   (a)    Any report submitted to Council by department heads, elected
officials, consultants or any other persons, shall be limited to the following:
(1)    One copy to the appropriate committee chairman.
(2)    One copy to any other member of Council who, for one reason or another
may need a copy.
(3)    One copy to the Clerk of Council for the files of Council.
   (b)    Any member of Council not supplied with a copy of a report as
previously outlined may, should he or she desire to be supplied with such a
copy, request the Clerk of Council to supply him or her with such a copy. The
Clerk of Council shall honor any such request within a reasonable time.
(Ord. 9660/86. Passed 4-9-86. )
CHAPTER 113
Ordinances and Resolutions
113.01 Publishing; preparation.
CROSS REFERENCES
Newspaper publication - see Ohio R. C. 7.12, 701.04, 731.21 et seq.
Adoption and style - see Ohio R. C. 715.03, 731.17 et seq.

Publication in book form - see Ohio R. C. 731.23

Emergency measures - see Ohio R. C. 731.30

   113.01  PUBLISHING; PREPARATION.
   (a)    Each ordinance and resolution which is prepared by the Director of
Law for each session of Council, on and after May 22, 1986 shall contain a
title which shall be a succinct summary of such ordinance or resolution and
shall have been reviewed prior to forwarding to Council to insure that the
summary, as contained in such title, is legally accurate and sufficient.
   (b)    Passage of an ordinance or resolution containing such summary as
contained in the title as prepared by the Director of Law shall be deemed
sufficient compliance with the provisions of Ohio R. C. 731.21 and the Clerk of
Council is hereby directed and authorized to publish the summary thereof in
compliance with Ohio R. C. 731.21, 731.22, 731.24 and 731.25, unless notified
otherwise by the Director of Law within three days after the passage thereof.
   (c)    If the amendment of an ordinance or resolution or other matters
pertaining thereto, should cause the Director of Law to revise the summary as
contained in the title, the Director of Law shall make such revision to the
title as is necessary to comply with Ohio R.C. 731.21 and forward such revised
title and summary to the Clerk of Council, without further action of Council,
and the Clerk shall proceed to the publication thereof as provided in the
applicable provisions of the Ohio Revised Code.
   (d)    The publication of ordinances and resolutions by summary as herein
provided shall provide notice that the complete text of such ordinance or
resolution may be viewed or obtained at the office of the Clerk of Council. 
The Clerk of Council shall supply a copy of the complete text of any such
ordinance or resolution to any person upon request and for such copy a fee
shall be charged and collected by the Clerk.  The Clerk shall post a copy of
the text of any ordinance or resolution at the office of the Clerk of Council.
   (e)    For the purpose also of providing for the provisions of this
ordinance within the Rules of Council, such Rules are hereby amended by
providing that subsection (a) hereof be enacted as Section 8.10, subsection (b)
hereof be enacted as Section 8.11, subsection (c) hereof be enacted as Section
8.12 and subsection (d) hereof be enacted as Section 8.13 of such Rules.
(Ord. 9662/86. Passed 4-23-86.)

   121.01  ADMINISTRATIVE ASSISTANT.
   (a)    There is hereby created within the administrative office of the
Mayor, the position of Administrative Assistant to the Mayor.
   (b)    The Administrative Assistant to the Mayor shall report directly to
the Mayor and act on behalf of the Mayor in all matters concerning the
operation and planning for the City. The Administrative Assistant, through the
authority of the Safety-Service Director, would be responsible for the
operations and future planning of the City.
(Ord. 8889/80. Passed 3-12-80.)
   121.02  ANNUAL APPROPRIATION MEASURE.
   A proposed, balanced annual appropriation measure shall be submitted by the
Mayor to City Council no later than the Monday preceding the first regular
meeting of City Council for December of the calendar year immediately preceding
the calendar year for which the proposed annual appropriation measure is
intended.
(Ord. 11860/05.  Passed 5-11-05.)

   123.01  CITY AUDITOR.
   The City Auditor’s office shall be composed of the City Auditor and such
other employees as may be authorized by Council.
(Ord. 6172/63.  Passed 12-2-63.)
   123.02  ASSISTANTS TO AUDITOR.
   The City Auditor is empowered to appoint and employ such assistants as may
be authorized by Council and whose duties shall relate to such office and in
such capacities as the Auditor may designate.
(1963 Code §123.02)
   123.03  INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the City that will not be
required to be used for a period of six months or more, such moneys may, in
lieu of being deposited in a bank or banks or otherwise invested, be invested
in accordance with the provisions of Ohio R.C. 731.56, 731.57, 731.58 and
731.59.  Investments so purchased shall be sold in accordance with Ohio R.C.
731.57.
(Ord. 10959/96.  Passed 10-9-96.)
   123.04  USE OF ELECTRONIC OR MECHANICAL SIGNATURES.
   (a)   Council authorizes the Auditor to prepare and utilize a facsimile
signature, in lieu of his manual signature, and to affix such facsimile
signature to any of the following instruments:  checks; drafts; warrants;
vouchers; or other instruments for the payment of money and necessary or
desirable in connection with the withdrawal of City funds for and on its
behalf.  The Auditor may affix his manual or facsimile signature to the
instruments identified so long as he continues to act as such officer/
employee.  The use of facsimile signatures is expressly approved by Council. 
Said checks, drafts, warrants, vouchers, or other instruments for the payment
of money may be drawn or relate to the accounts of the City with the various
financial institutions (depositories/banks) with which the City conducts
business.  The Auditor is directed to provide written notice of the use of any
facsimile signature to the depository from which the funds are to be drawn.
   (b)   Council directs that the financial institutions (depositories/banks),
with which the City does business, are authorized and requested to accept,
honor, cash, pay or transfer, without limit as to the amount or without further
inquiry, checks bearing the authorized signature(s) as provided by the
immediately preceding paragraph whether tendered in payment of an individual
obligation or deposited in the account of the City.
   (c)   Facsimile signature is defined to include, but is not limited to, the
reproduction of any authorized signature by a copper plate or by a
photographic, photo static or mechanical device.  Facsimile signature does not
authorize the use of a rubber stamp signature for any of the instruments
detailed above.
   (d)   In order to protect the City and its employees from loss, damage or
expense occasioned by the unauthorized use of a facsimile signature, the
Council directs the Auditor to procure for the City and for the individuals
identified above a surety bond in such amount as approved by the Law Director.
   (e)   The actual facsimile signature should be maintained under the care,
custody and control of the Auditor and, as further precaution, all checks must
be entered into the check register so that all numbers can be accounted for.
(Ord. 12091/08.  Passed 2-27-08.)

   125.01  INCOME TAX DEPARTMENT.
   There is hereby established the Income Tax Department in the office of the
City Treasurer, such Department to be composed of such employees as may be
authorized by Council. 
(Ord.  6172/63.  Passed 12-2-63.)
   125.02  TAX ADMINISTRATOR.
   (a)   The City Treasurer shall appoint a Tax Administrator.  The Tax
Administrator shall report directly to the City Treasurer.  The Tax
Administrator shall serve at the pleasure of the City Treasurer.
   (b)   A person appointed to the position of Tax Administrator must have:
      (1)   Received from an accredited college or university at least a
bachelor’s degree in finance, accounting or related business field (prior tax
administration experience being highly preferred); and
      (2)   Supervisory skills (prior supervisory experience is highly
preferred); and
      (3)   Data processing knowledge and basic experience in the use of
computer software.
   (c)   At the request of the City Treasurer, and under the direction of the
City Treasurer, the Human Resources Department of the City shall seek qualified
applicants for the position of Tax Administrator by appropriate means such as
advertising; and assist with the screening, interviewing, hiring and post-
hiring process.
   (d)   The primary duty of the Tax Administrator is assuring that the income
tax ordinances of the City are fully enforced.  This includes, but is not
limited to, planning, supervising and assisting in the work of income tax
collection.  The Tax Administrator shall supervise the staff assigned to assist
with income tax law enforcement and collection of income taxes.  The Tax
Administrator shall insure proper tax reporting by all employers whose
employees perform duties within the City; collect income taxes, including
estimated and withholding taxes, using appropriate means including judicial
recovery if necessary; assure proper filing of returns by any employers,
employees and residents of the City; approve tax refunds and submit same for
payment; post all taxes to appropriate accounts; receive and process income tax
returns; and assure that standard accounting and finance security measures are
in place and working.  The Tax Administrator shall be fully knowledgeable of
all City income tax ordinances as well as state and federal laws which impact
on the Tax Administrator’s duties.
   (e)   The position of Tax Administrator is subject to the residence
requirements of the Codified Ordinances of the City.
(Ord.  11484/01.  Passed 8-22-01.)
CHAPTER 127
Director of Law
127.01   Composition of office.
127.02   Assistants.
127.03   Compromise settlement of claims.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Election and term - see Ohio R.C. 733.49
         Qualifications - see Ohio R.C. 733.50
         Powers and duties - see Ohio R.C. 733.51 et seq.

171.13
   127.01  COMPOSITION OF OFFICE.
   The office of the Director of Law shall be composed of the Law Director and
such other employees as may be authorized by Council.
(Ord.  6172/63.  Passed 12-2-63.)
   127.02  ASSISTANTS.
   The Law Director is authorized to appoint and employ one or more
assistants.  The Law Director may select an assistant to act in the capacity of
a prosecuting attorney in the Municipal Court.  No person shall be eligible for
such appointment who is not an attorney and counselor at law duly admitted to
practice within the State.  Such assistant shall serve during the term
concurrent with that of the Law Director, but such appointment may be
terminated at the pleasure of the Law Director.
(Ord.  5847/61.  Passed 12-18-61.)
   127.03  COMPROMISE SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS.
   (a)   The Director of Law, or his designated assistant, is authorized to
enter into compromise settlement of claims against the City, resolution of
which do not exceed the sum of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500). 
Claims that cannot be so settled shall be referred to the Claims Review Board.
   The City Auditor and the City Treasurer are authorized and directed to pay
such claims, upon receipt of vouchers approved by the Law Director or his
designated representative.
   (b)   A Claims Review Board is hereby established, for the purpose of
examining claims against the City and recommending means of settlement.  The
Claims Review Board is comprised of the Law Director or his designated
assistant; the Finance Director or his representative and the Safety-Service
Director or his representative.  The Board is hereby authorized to enter into
compromise settlement of claims against the City, resolution of which do not
exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000).  Claims that cannot be so settled shall
be referred to the Finance Committee of Council and thereby be brought to the
attention of Council.
   The City Auditor and the City Treasurer are authorized and directed to pay
such claims, upon receipt of vouchers approved by the Board.
   (c)   The Law Director or his designated assistant shall report to the Board
and to the Finance Committee of Council on a monthly basis as to the status of
claims against the City.
   (d)   All such settlements shall be paid out of the claims account of the
appropriate fund. 
(Ord.  9910/88.  Passed 4-27-88.)

   129.08  ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES DEPARTMENT.

Department of Public Service and Safety, composed of the Director of

Council.
(Ord.  11510/01.  Passed 11-28-01.)

   129.11  ADMINISTRATIVE AND PURCHASING COORDINATOR.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Administrative and Purchasing
Coordinator under the control and direction of the Director of Public Service
and Safety.
   (b)   The duties of the Administrative and Purchasing Coordinator shall be:
(1)    Prepare bid specifications and other necessary documents related to the
purchase of supplies, materials, services and equipment.
(2)    Receive, examine and process requisitions and determine the priority of
purchases.
(3)    Consult with appropriate vendors and receive and list quotations and
bids for the best prices consistent with specifications.
(4)    Prepare proposals, issue purchase orders and recommend the award of
contracts to vendors for purchases.
(5)    Verify commodity and service quality, attend bid openings and report all
pertinent information related to the bid process.
(6)    Coordinate and consolidate the needs of the various City departments and
divisions for the purchase of supplies, materials, services and equipment.
(7)    Keep records and files of items purchased and price quotations of items
required for the operation of the departments and divisions.
(8)    Review all bills and invoices prior to payment.
(9)    Supervise the work of employees of the Procurement Office and establish
the methods and procedures thereof.
(10)    Review and consolidate the budget requests of the various departments
and divisions of the City and assist in the preparation of the annual budget of
the City.
(11)    Perform such other duties as may be designated by the Director of
Public Service and Safety.
   (c)    The Administrative and Purchasing Coordinator shall have as one of
his qualifications not less than three years' experience in a recognized
purchasing department.
(Ord. 6552/66. Passed 2-7-66.)
   129.12  SIDEWALK DEPARTMENT.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
129.12  was repealed by Ordinance 9511/84, passed November 14, 1984.)
   129.13  CITY JAIL.
   (a)    There is hereby established and shall be maintained in the City, a
City jail in the Municipal Justice Center.
   (b)    The City jail may be used for the confinement of such persons as are
arrested and held for trial for the violation of any ordinance of the City, or
for the confinement of any other persons who are arrested for the violation of
any State or United States Statute when the arrest is made by any police
officer of the City, or by the assistance of any such officer, and when the
confinement in the jail for the violation of the State or the United States
Statute is temporary only.
   (c)    The Director of Public Service and Safety shall make necessary and
proper provisions for the maintenance, support and care of all persons confined
in the City jail and the maintenance of the jail itself in a safe, clean and
healthful condition.
   (d)    Under the supervision of the Director of Public Service and Safety,
the Chief of the Police Department, or other police officers under his
direction and instructions, shall see that all prisoners who are confined in
the City jail are properly provided with food, sustenance and, if necessary,
medical and surgical attention, and that the jail is warmed and ventilated and
comfortable bedding furnished therefor.
(1963 Code §173.01 - 173.04)
   129.14  DEPARTMENT OF HUMAN RESOURCES.
   (a)    There is hereby established a Department of Human Resources within
the Department of Public Service and Safety to be composed of a Personnel
Director and such other employees as may be authorized by Council.
   (b)    The Personnel Director shall have as part of his/her qualifications
not less than a bachelor's degree, preferably with a major in public, personnel
or business administration, and not less than five years' experience in the
management of personnel.
   (c)    The Department of Human Resources shall coordinate the personnel
functions of the City.
(Ord. 9311/83. Passed 4-13-83.)
   129.15  OPERATIONS DEPARTMENT.
   The Operations Department is composed of Street, Construction, Park,
Maintenance and Storm Water Utility Divisions, within the Department of Public
Service and Safety. The Operations Department shall continue to be composed of
a department head known as the Director of Service Operations and other such
employees as may be authorized by Council.
(Ord. 10645/94. Passed 3-3-94.)
   129.16  DATA PROCESS SYSTEMS DEPARTMENT.
   (a)    There is hereby established a Data Process Systems Department within
the Department of Public Service and Safety to be composed of a Manager of Data
Process Systems and such other employees as may be authorized by Council.
   (b)    The Data Process Systems Department shall coordinate the computer-
related functions of the City.
(Ord. 9627/85, Passed 12-11-85.)
   129.17  REWARD ACCOUNT.
   (a)   There is hereby created an account within the accounts of the
Operations Department to be used for the purpose of paying rewards to persons
who provide information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons who
violate those City ordinances or laws of the State which prohibit vandalism and
other like offenses within the City parks.
   (b)   The Director of Public Service and Safety is hereby authorized to make
payments of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per person, per payment to persons
who provide information leading to the arrest and conviction of persons who
have violated those City ordinances or laws of the State which prohibit
vandalism and other like offenses within the City parks.  Any such reward
payments shall be made after recommendation of the Chief of Police or the head
of the Operations Department.  Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this
section, no more than one such reward payment of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
may be paid per occurrence, regardless of the number of persons providing any
information.
   (c)   The City Auditor and the City Treasurer are hereby authorized to
disburse such funds upon receipt of proper vouchers, signed by the proper
persons, for the stated purpose and for no other purpose.
   (d)   The above account is hereby created to promote resident involvement in
promoting the integrity of the City parks, and all moneys credited to such
account shall only be expended for the purpose intended.
(Ord. 10261/91.  Passed 5-29-91.)
   129.18  PROCEDURE FOR SALE OF CITY REAL ESTATE.
   Except as otherwise provided by law, on a finding by Council that City-owned
real estate is not needed for public use, the property shall be advertised for
sale once a week for two consecutive weeks in a newspaper of general
circulation within the City, and shall be conveyed to the highest bidder upon
approval of the Board of Control.  However, except as otherwise provided by
law, advertising may be dispensed with and the sale made to a named grantee at
a fixed price when Council specifically so authorizes by the two-thirds vote of
its members.
(Ord. 10933/96.  Passed 7-24-96.)
   129.19  PURCHASE OF SERVICES AND SUPPLIES VIA REVERSE  AUCTION ON INTERNET.
   (a)   As used in this section:
      (1)   “The City” means the City of Warren, Ohio.
      (2)   “Internet” means the international computer network of both federal
and nonfederal interoperable pocket switched data networks, including the
graphical subnetwork called the world wide web.
      (3)   “Reverse auction” means a purchasing process in which offerors
submit proposals in competing to sell services or supplies in an open
environment via the internet.
      (4)   “Services” means the furnishing of labor, time, or effort by a
person, not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than a
report which, if provided, is merely incidental to the required performance. 
“Services” does not include services furnished pursuant to employment
agreements or collective bargaining agreements.
      (5)   “Supplies” means all property, including, but not limited to,
equipment, materials, other tangible assets, and insurance, but excluding real
property or interests in real property.
   (b)   Whenever the City is required by law to purchase services or supplies
by competitive sealed bidding or competitive sealed proposals, the City may
purchase such services or supplies by reverse auction should the City determine
that the use of a reverse auction is advantageous to the City.  Any use of a
reverse auction shall be in accordance with state statute, this section, and
any other applicable ordinances of the City.
   (c)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City shall solicit proposals
through a request for proposals.  The request for proposals shall state the
relative importance of price and other evaluation factors.  The City shall give
notice of the request for proposals by and through its website located at
www.warren.org (or any successor website).  Offerors may also register on-line
to be notified automatically of proposal opportunities.
   (d)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City may:
   (1)   On an auction-by-auction basis, determine in advance the maximum price
that the City is able or willing to procure a service or supply for, and then
post on the request for proposal that price as the “ceiling price” for that
service or supply.
      (2)   On an auction-by-auction basis, require a fee to be paid by each
offeror for the download of information on the website.  Any such fee shall be
reasonable and shall be based upon the cost to the City of such activity.
      (3)   On an auction-by-auction basis, and to ensure full understanding of
and responsiveness to solicitation requirements, conduct discussions with
responsible offerors who submit proposals determined to be reasonably
susceptible of being selected for award.  The City shall accord offerors fair
and equal treatment with respect to any opportunity for discussion regarding
any clarification, correction or revision of their proposals.
   (e)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City shall post on a request
for proposal:
      (1)   An itemized list of the service or supply to be procured, including
the quantity thereof.
      (2)   The date and duration of the auction.
      (3)   The date any proposal is due in to the City.
      (4)   The method by which any proposal shall be submitted to the City,
which shall include electronic submission, mail, courier service, or personal
delivery.
      (5)   The name and address to which any proposal shall be submitted.
      (6)   Whether or not any particular bond(s) is required.
      (7)   Whether or not any particular fee is required from an offeror.
      (8)   Whether or not the City will conduct discussions with responsible
offerors who submit proposals to be reasonably susceptible of being selected
for award.
      (9)   Any other instructions or conditions for participation.
      (10)   Any other information or matters required by law or ordinance.
   (f)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City shall:
      (1)   Notify each successful offeror of that fact within ten (10)
business days after the end date of the auction.  Such notice may be made by
email.
      (2)   Post conspicuously and continuously on the City’s aforementioned
website the fact that the City can, and does, procure services and supplies by
reverse auction.
      (3)   Post conspicuously and continuously in a public place in Warren
City Hall the fact that the City can, and does, procure services and supplies
by reverse auction.
      (4)   Require that each successful offeror post a performance bond (or
other form of financial security) in the amount of the contract, payable to the
City, and conditioned that the successful offeror will faithfully execute the
terms of the contract.
      (5)   Comply with all applicable terms and conditions required by law or
ordinance.
   (g)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City shall, and does, reserve
the right to accept or reject any proposal, in whole or in part, and to waive
any informalities or irregularities in any proposal received.
   (h)   In making use of a reverse auction, the City may award a contract to
the offeror whose proposal the City determines to be the most advantageous to
the City taking into consideration factors such as price and the evaluation
criteria set forth in the request for proposals.  The contract file shall
contain the basis upon which the award is made.
   (i)   Any purchasing preferences or public contracting preferences that
favor Ohio mined, excavated, produced, manufactured, raised or grown products
or Ohio-based contractors shall not apply to or affect purchases by the City of
services or supplies by reverse auction.
   (j)   The City assumes no responsibility for, and shall have no
responsibility for, costs incurred by any offeror prior to the award of any
contract resulting from reverse auction.
(Ord. 11758/04.  Passed 3-10-04.)
   129.20  CONTRACTS AUTHORIZED BY ORDINANCE.
   Any contract to be entered into by the Director of Public Service and Safety
per Sections 735.05 et seq. or 737.03 et seq. of the Ohio Revised Code
involving more than the dollar limitation then specified within those sections
shall first be authorized and directed by ordinance of City Council, regardless
of whether or not that contract may be for equipment, services, materials or
supplies that can be purchased by the Director of Public Service and Safety
under Sections 125.04 or 5513.01 of the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 11841/05.  Passed 3-9-05.)

   131.01  ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is established a Police Department, within the Department of Public
Service and Safety, to be composed of a Police Chief and such other officers
and men as may be authorized by Council.
(Ord. 6172/63. Passed 12-2-63.)
   131.02  DUTIES OF POLICE CHIEF.
   It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police to have charge of the Police
Department and to have exclusive control of stationing and transfer for all
patrolmen, officers and employees in the Department, under such general rules
and regulations as the Director of Public Service and Safety may prescribe.
(Ord. 9643/86. Passed 2-12-86.)
   131.03  ADDITIONAL DUTIES OF POLICE CHIEF.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section
131.03  was repealed by Ordinance 10669/94, passed May 25, 1994.)
   131.04  COPIES OF POLICE REPORTS; FINGERPRINTING SERVICES.
   (a)   Photostatic copies of police reports, to which the public is entitled
to be given by law, or otherwise, shall be furnished to interested parties, or
their representatives, at reasonable times upon request duly made.  There shall
be collected at the time that any such photostatic copy is furnished the actual
cost for each such report photocopied.
   (b)   Police reports to which the public is entitled to be given by law, or
otherwise, shall be checked by the Police Department within a reasonable time
upon request duly made.  There shall be collected upon the conclusion of any
such record check a charge representing the actual cost of each such record
checked.
   (c)   Fingerprinting services shall be provided to the public by the Police
Department within a reasonable time upon request duly made.  Except for
fingerprinting services provided pursuant to a child identification program or
provided relative to alien registration for citizenship, which shall be
provided at no charge, a charge of ten dollars ($10.00) per person
fingerprinted shall be collected upon the rendering of any such fingerprinting
services.  The Chief of Police may waive this fee upon good cause shown.
(Ord. 10964/96.  Passed 10-23-96.)
   131.05  PRIVATE POLICE.
   (a)    Appointment. The Director of Public Service and Safety is authorized
and empowered to appoint and commission private police officers, upon the
application of the board of directors or trustees of any agricultural society,
cemetery association, park or hospital; or upon the application of the owner of
a tenement house or of any private grounds or buildings, shop, factory,
manufacturing plant, store, warehouse or other place or structure; or in any
case when in the opinion of the Director, the services of the private police
are necessary for the proper protection of life and property, or the
maintenance of order.
   (b)    Term; Authority. Private police officers shall have all the powers
and exercise all the authority of regular police officers in the enforcement of
the laws of the United States, the laws of the State, and the provisions of the
Codified Ordinances and other ordinances of the City, and be limited
specifically to the locality and the vicinity or place for which they shall be
appointed.
   (c)    Bonds. All private police officers, before receiving their
commissions, shall comply with provisions of Section
549.02  of the General Offenses Code, and shall show evidence of a performance
bond of one thousand dollars ($1,000) and liability insurance of one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000) to the satisfaction of the Director of Public
Service and Safety.
   (d)    General Regulations. Private police officers appointed and
commissioned as provided in the preceding subsections shall receive no
compensation from the City, unless called into the service of the City. They
shall not be subject to the law or rules governing the appointment to office in
the Police Department under the merit system, but shall be subject to such
rules and regulations as shall be promulgated from time to time by the Director
of Public Service and Safety for the regulation and discipline of private
police officers, and may be removed by the Director at any time for any cause
deemed sufficient and reasonable by the Director.
(Ord. 9070/81. Passed 7-8-81.)
   (e)    Qualifications. The Director of Public Service and Safety shall
require that each applicant for a private police officer commission be
certified by the Peace Officers Training Commission of Ohio. They shall be
required to show proof of completion and certification of the specified number
of training hours required by the State of Ohio for Municipal Police Officers.
   Each applicant shall be required to submit to a validation process deemed
appropriate by the Director and accomplished by the policing authority. This
process shall include, but not be limited to, a background investigation,
fingerprints recorded, psychological profile, if one can be done at a
reasonable cost, photographs, etc. A validated identification card shall be
issued to each applicant subsequently commissioned.
(Ord. 9643/86. Passed 2-12-86.)
   (f)    Emergency Service. Private policemen shall at all times be subject to
being called into the service of the City. When called into the service of the
City, they shall receive like compensation as special policemen. Such private
policemen shall be called into the service of the City only in the case of a
riot or like emergency under the appointment powers of the Mayor as contained
in and subject to the provisions of Ohio R. C. 737.10 and shall only be
employed for the time such emergency exists.
   (g)    Definition. For purposes of this section, "riot" means a situation
where four or more persons participate with each other in a course of
disorderly conduct in violation of the Codified Ordinances or a situation where
four or more persons participate with each other with purpose to do an act with
unlawful force or violence, even though such act might otherwise be lawful.
   (h)    Strikebreaking. It is not the intention of this section to permit
such private policemen to be called into the service of the City solely for the
purpose of having them act as strikebreakers in a labor dispute between the
City and the members of the Police Department.
   (i)    Fees.  Private police officers shall be appointed and commissioned
for a period not exceeding one year. The initial commission issued by the
Director of Public Service and Safety shall have a fee assessed of fifty
dollars ($50.00). Renewal of commissions shall be at an annual rate of ten
dollars ($10.00). Funds derived from these fees shall be credited to the
Special Police Equipment Fund for the exclusive use of the Police Department.
(Ord. 9070/81. Passed 7-8-81.)
   131.06  AUXILIARY POLICE PROGRAM.
   A City of Warren Auxiliary Police program is hereby established under the
leadership and authority of the Police Department through the Director of
Public Service and Safety.
(Ord. 7197/70. Passed 9-8-70.)
   131.07  POLICE OFFICERS.
   A policy is hereby enacted governing the appointment of provisional officers
within the Police Department.
(a)    The following shall be considered guidelines to be utilized in the
selection process for Police Officers. In no way shall this section be
considered as establishing maximum requirements, but shall be considered as
establishing minimal requirements within the selection process.
(b)    The selection process for Police Officer shall be administered by the
Civil Service Commission and in no way shall this section be considered in
conflict with the State civil service law. The selection process shall include,
but not be limited to, the following criteria:
(1)    Satisfactory completion of a thoroughly designed application form;
(2)    Satisfactory completion of a thorough and detailed background
investigation;
(3)    Satisfactory completion of a thorough agility fitness examination which
accurately depicts the appropriate duties of a police officer;
(4)    Satisfactory completion of a thorough physical examination by a medical
doctor;
(5)    Satisfactory completion of a polygraph examination to verify all
background information;
(6)    Satisfactory completion of a thorough psychological profile which may be
oral or written:
A.    If oral, the examination must be given by a licensed psychologist with a
background in police officer evaluation.
B.    If written, the examination may be administered locally by the Civil
Service Commission but must be evaluated by a competent psychologist with a
background in the evaluation of police officers.
   (Ord. 9643/86. Passed 2-12-86.)
   131.08  DISPOSITION OF PROPERTY.
   (a)    The Chief of Police is hereby authorized and directed to exert and
implement, when applicable, on behalf of the City and the Police Department,
each and every applicable provision of Ohio R.C. 2933.41.
   (b)    The proceeds from property disposed of pursuant to Ohio R. C. 2933.41
and this section shall be placed into the City's General Fund.
(Ord. 9404/83. Passed 12-14-83.)
   131.09  AUXILIARY, VOLUNTEER HANDICAP PARKING ENFORCEMENT PROGRAM.
   An auxiliary, volunteer unit is hereby created and established within the
Police Department of the City for the purpose of assisting the Department in
the enforcement of those ordinances of the City which restrict parking of motor
vehicles in handicap parking areas. Such unit shall be known as the "Auxiliary,
Volunteer Handicap Parking Enforcement Unit" hereinafter in this section
referred to as "the Unit".
   The members of the Unit each of whom shall be a volunteer and at least
twenty-one years of age, shall be appointed by the Director of Public Service
and Safety. Each member shall serve so long as the Director may direct.
   The Chief of Police shall be the commanding officer of the Unit and shall
have control of the assignment, training, stationing and direction of work of
the Unit. The members of the Unit shall obey the chain of command of the Police
Department of the City and shall take orders from all regular appointed members
thereof. The members of the Unit shall, and hereby do, have authority to issue
citations for parking violations, but only as to violations of Section
351.04 (e) or other like ordinances of the City, which restrict parking of
motor vehicles in handicap parking areas. All services performed by members of
the Unit shall be on a voluntary basis and within the City.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall prescribe rules and
regulations, not inconsistent with this section for the organization, training,
administration, conduct and control of the Unit.
(Ord. 9810/87. Passed 7-29-87.)
   131.10  POLICE PROTECTION OUTSIDE CITY.
   The Chief of Police is hereby designated, in accordance with Ohio R.C.
737.041, to authorize the rendering of police services to other subdivisions of
the State of Ohio and adjoining states without a contract subject to review and
approval by the Director of Public Service and Safety.
   Ohio R.C. Chapter 2744 (political subdivision tort liability) insofar as it
applies to the operation of police departments shall apply to the City and the
members of its Police Department when such members are rendering police
services pursuant to Ohio R.C. 737.041.
   Regular police officers of the City while acting outside the City limits
shall be entitled to participate in any established pension fund to the same
extent as while acting within the City. Such member shall be entitled to all of
the rights of Ohio R.C. 4123.01-4123.96 to the same extent as while performing
services within the City.
(Ord. 10182/90. Passed 11-14-90.)
   131.11 MOTOR VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT AND TOWING FEE.
   (a)   Whenever a motor vehicle is towed, removed, ordered into storage or
impounded at the behest of a Warren City police officer, the owner of said
vehicle shall be responsible to pay a fee to the City of Warren representing
ordinary, usual and reasonable expenses of the City of Warren incurred as a
result of such towing, removal, ordering into storage or impoundment.  Such fee
shall be, and is, seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
   (b)   The fee provided for in subsection (a) hereof shall be paid by the
owner to the City at the time that the owner appears at the Warren Police
Department for the purpose of securing a release authorization form.  No such
release authorization form shall be issued unless and until said fee is paid in
full.
   (c)   The fee provided for in subsection (a) hereof shall be, and is, in
addition to any fine and any other fee or charge provided for in the Codified
Ordinances of the City of Warren or elsewhere.
(Ord. 12217/09.  Passed 9-9-09.)
   (d)   All fees collected per this section shall be deposited into the City’s
General Fund, credited to the Police Department, and used solely for the
purchase of motor vehicles for the Police Department.
(Ord. 12370/11.  Passed 11-7-11.)
   (e)   Any person whose vehicle has been towed and/or impounded and who has
not been cited for any City Code Violation, City Ordinance or State Law shall
be exempted from payment of fees created by this section. 
(Ord. 12613/15.  Passed 10-28-15.)

CHAPTER 135
