CHAPTER 701
Licensing Generally
701.01   License issuance.
701.02   License information.
701.03   Transferability.
701.04   Revocation.
701.05   Mayor's signature.
701.06   Disposition of fees.
701.07   Records to be kept.   
701.08   Monthly report by Mayor.
701.09   Exhibit upon demand; right of entry.
701.10   Exceptions.
701.11   Compliance with Municipal income tax.
701.12   Appeals; Board of Appeals.
701.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to license - see Ohio R. C. 715.60 et seq.
Income tax declarations - see ADM.
171.07
   701.01  LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   The Mayor is authorized and empowered and it shall be a part of his duties
to allow, sign and issue all licenses provided for by this Part Seven -
Business Regulation Code, and to collect the charges for such licenses. The
Health Commissioner may act as the Mayor's designated agent for the purpose of
administering the provisions contained herein.
   701.02  LICENSE INFORMATION.
   Every license issued by the Mayor shall give the name of the person who is
authorized to do business thereunder, the purpose for which it is granted and
the time it is to be in force, and if it authorizes the licensee to do business
at some particular place, the location where the same may be used.
(1963 Code §701.02)
   701.03  TRANSFERABILITY.
   A license granted or issued under any of the provisions of this Code shall
not be assignable or transferable, or authorize any person other than is
therein named to do business
thereunder.
(1963 Code §701.03)
   701.04  REVOCATION.
   Except as otherwise provided in this Code, if at any time it shall be made
to appear to the satisfaction of the Mayor that any licensed person has
violated any State statute or ordinance of this City applying to such license
or has been convicted of a felony or any act involving moral turpitude, the
Mayor may revoke his license and such licensed person shall cease to have any
authority thereunder.
(1963 Code §701.04)
   701.05  MAYOR'S SIGNATURE.
   No license issued under the provisions of this Code shall be valid until
signed by the Mayor.
(1963 Code § 701.05)
   701.06  DISPOSITION OF FEES.
   Each license fee collected under the provisions of this Code shall be paid
into the City Treasury by the Mayor, upon the warrant of the City Auditor, the
Mayor taking the Treasurer's receipt therefor.
(1963 Code § 701.06)
   701.07  RECORDS TO BE KEPT.
   The Mayor shall keep a record of all licenses issued showing when, to whom
and for what purpose and for how long a time the same was granted, and collect
and keep a record of the money paid for the same.
(1963 Code §701.07)
   701.08  MONTHLY REPORT BY MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall make a detailed statement of all license fees collected by
him during the month, and report the same to Council at the first meeting in
each month, with the Treasurer's receipt therefor.
(1963 Code § 701.08)
   701.09  EXHIBIT UPON DEMAND; RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   Upon demand being made by any police officer of the City, any licensee shall
show his license. The refusal by such person to show any police officer such
license shall be deemed prima-facie evidence that such person has not obtained
a license as herein required. For the purpose of preserving good order, every
police officer of the City shall have the right of ingress and egress to any
place of exhibition or performance licensed by this Code.
(1963 Code §701.09)
   701.10  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this Code shall not apply to any officer selling goods
under judicial process, nor be construed to require of the vendor of any
product of his own raising, or the vendor of any article manufactured by
himself, to take out a license to vend or sell in any way, by himself or agent,
any such article or product; nor to any person selling or offering for sale,
fruits, vegetables, meats, produce or other articles, the product of his farm
or rented land, nor to children under the age of sixteen years who peddle
fruits, candies, nuts, cakes or refreshments or newspapers; provided, that they
do not occupy a stand on any street or public ground in the City, nor sold for
charitable, benevolent or church purposes. Also, for lectures on scientific,
historic or literary subjects, musical parties or concerts, exhibition given or
made by citizens of this City or for charitable, benevolent or church purposes,
no license or permit shall be required.
(1963 Code §701.10)
   701.11  COMPLIANCE WITH MUNICIPAL INCOME TAX.
   Before any permit or license may be issued pursuant to this Code to any
person or firm that is not domiciled within the City, such person or firm must
first comply with the provisions of Section
171.07, "Declarations" of the Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 7440/72. Passed 4-17-72.)
   701.12  APPEALS; BOARD OF APPEALS.
   Whenever any license provided for in Part Seven - Business Regulation Code
is refused, suspended or revoked by the Mayor, or other proper official duly
empowered to do so, such licensee or applicant may appeal from such suspension,
refusal or revocation to a Board of Appeals composed of three residents
appointed by the Mayor. Notice of such appeal shall be in writing and delivered
to the office of the Mayor within ten days from the making of such order. The
Board of Appeals shall fix the time of hearing of such appeal, at which hearing
all parties interested shall be afforded an opportunity to be heard and such
Board of Appeals may sustain, disapprove or modify such order, and its decision
shall be final.
   701.99  PENALTY.
   Whenever in this Part Seven - Business Regulation Code any act is prohibited
or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or
whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any
ordinance shall be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars
($500.00), or imprisonment for six months, or both. Each day any violation of
any provision of this Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute
a separate offense.
(1963 Code §701.99)
CHAPTER 705
Police Alarm Systems
705.01   Definitions.
705.02   Registration required; fee.
705.03   Signal devices.
705.04   Leased lines. 
705.05   Fees.
705.06   Cancellation.
705.07   False alarm response fee.
705.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Automobile alarm device - see TRAF.
337.19(b)
Making false alarms - see GEN. OFF.
509.11
School fire alarm systems - see FIRE PREV.
1505.08
Fire alarm systems - see FIRE PREV. Ch.
1510
   705.01  DEFINITIONS.
   (a)    "False alarm", as used in this chapter, means an alarm signal
necessitating response by the Police Department and resulting not from the
existence of an emergency situation but from defect or malfunction.
   (b)    "The maximum permissible number of false alarms", as used in this
chapter, means one false alarm in any thirty day period, two false alarms in
any ninety day period, three false alarms in any 180 day period or four false
alarms in any 360 day period.
(Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.02  REGISTRATION REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)    Every individual, partnership, company, corporation or utility
engaged in the business of sales, service and installation of burglar or
robbery alarm systems or any combination of burglar-fire-robbery alarm systems
shall be registered to engage in such business in the City.
   (b)    The fee for such registration shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per year or any part of a year and shall expire December 31 of each year.
   (c)    The Mayor shall have the right to cancel any registration issued
pursuant to this section for the following reasons:
(1)    Violation by the registered person of any provision of this chapter; or
(2)    When the registered person or any of his employees is convicted or found
guilty of a crime involving moral turpitude; or
(3)    Where the character, reputation or moral integrity of the registered
person or any of his employees is determined inimical to the public safety or
the general welfare of the community; or
(4)    Where a burglar alarm system or robbery alarm system or any combination
of burglar-fire-robbery alarm system attributable to the registered person
emits more than the maximum permissible number of false alarms; or
(5)    Where the registered person or his employee or agent knowingly made any
false, misleading or fraudulent statement of a material fact in the application
for the license issued pursuant to this section.
         (Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.03  SIGNAL DEVICES.
   Any alarm system equipped to use a noise-making device such as a bell, horn
or siren shall be equipped with a timing device to automatically turn off the
noise-making device after having sounded for not more than five minutes and
shall remain off until the system has been corrected and reset manually.
(Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.04  LEASED LINES.
   The subscriber shall purchase and pay for leased lines to the police
station. The City shall furnish, at the police station, a control panel to
monitor the alarm system twenty-four hours per day, providing the following
requirements are met:
(a)    The installation of the alarm system shall be or shall have been
installed by someone licensed to make such installations by the City.
(b)    The control panel at the subscriber's residence or place of business
shall be of the type listed by Underwriters' Laboratories.
(c)    It shall be the subscriber's responsibility to determine if the system
is functioning properly over the leased lines and to a point located in the
alarm equipment room. Any system connected to the Police Department control
panel shall be compatible with the modules furnished by the City and used to
monitor such alarm system.
(d)    The City assumes no liability in the event any alarm fails to function
properly or is defeated in any way.
      (Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.05  FEES.
   (a)    Persons subscribing to the alarm monitoring service shall pay a fee
of sixty dollars ($60.00) for initial connection to the monitoring panel and
thirty-six dollars ($36.00) per year for monitoring service payable in advance.
In the event service should be discontinued for any reason, that portion of the
unused monitoring fee shall be returned to the subscriber prorated on a monthly
basis.
   (b)    All fees shall be collected by the Police Department and placed into
the General Fund.
(Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.06  CANCELLATION.
   The Director of Public Service and Safety shall have the right to cancel and
discontinue monitoring service of any subscriber for the following reasons:
(a)    Nonpayment of monitoring fees;
(b)    Violation of any provision of this chapter;
(c)    Where an alarm being monitored emits more than the maximum permissible
number of false alarms; or
(d)    For any reason where such monitoring service is not in the best
interests of the City.
      (Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
   705.07  FALSE ALARM RESPONSE FEE.
   For each activation of a residential or business burglar or other emergency
alarm system within the City resulting from equipment malfunction or human
error in excess of three of same per calendar year, a fee of twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) per activation shall be charged to, and paid by, the owner(s)
thereof.
(Ord. 10773/95. Passed 3-8-95.)
   705.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned not more than six months or both,
for each offense.
(Ord. 9698/86. Passed 7-23-86.)
CHAPTER 707
Auctions
707.01   Definitions.
707.02   Intent.
707.03   License required.
707.04   License application.
707.05   Bond required.
707.06   Issuance of license; fee.
707.07   Revocation of license.
707.08   Cappers, boosters prohibited.
707.09   False statements or misrepresentations.
707.10   Merchandise to be sold by pieces, sets or lots. 
707.11   Exceptions.
707.12   Violations.
707.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.24, 715.63
Conduct of auction sales - see Ohio R.C. 1315.22
Auctions - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1318
Examination and license fees - see Ohio R.C. 4707.08 et seq.
Jewelry auctions and going-out-of-business sales - see BUS. REG. Ch.
725
   707.01  DEFINITIONS.
   "Public auction" as used in this chapter means the sale or offering for sale
to the highest bidder any goods, wares or merchandise at retail in any
building, or in any other public place or home, where any and all persons who
choose are permitted to attend and offer bids, except that this chapter shall
not apply to warehouse or storage sales in satisfaction of liens, as provided
for in the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 8432/77. Passed 2-28-77.)
   707.02  INTENT.
   It is declared the legislative intent that auction sales, as herein defined,
includes auction barns as well as the sales held to liquidate estates and
businesses.
(Ord. 8432/77. Passed 2-28-77.)
   707.03  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person, by himself or by or through any agent or servant shall sell or
offer for sale at public auction any goods, wares or merchandise, whether he
sells or offers the same for sale for himself or as the agent, servant or
employee of another; unless such person shall first procure a license to do so
as provided in this chapter.
(1963 Code §707.03)
   707.04  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Any person desiring to hold an auction sale of the goods, wares or
merchandise allowed in this chapter, shall file a sworn written application
with the Mayor for a license stating the address of the applicant, the place
where the sale is to be conducted, a statement of the type of merchandise to be
offered, and the name and address of the auctioneer who will conduct the
proceedings.
(Ord. 8432/77. Passed 2-28-77.)
   707.05  BOND REQUIRED.
   Every applicant for a license, under the provisions of this chapter, shall
execute and file with the Mayor a good and sufficient bond in an amount equal
to the aggregate value of the goods, wares and merchandise to be sold, as shown
by the inventory with two sureties thereon, who shall be freeholders within the
City, or with a surety company authorized to do business in the State, as the
surety thereon. Such bond shall be to the approval of the Mayor. It shall be
conditioned upon the faithful observance of all the conditions of this chapter
and to indemnify any purchaser at any auction sale who suffers any loss by
reason of misrepresentations in such sale. Any purchaser claiming to have been
damaged by misrepresentation in any auction sale may maintain an action at law
against the licensee, making such misrepresentations, and may join as party
defendant the sureties on such bond as herein provided.
(1963 Code §707. 05)
   707.06  ISSUANCE OF LICENSE; FEE.
   The Mayor is authorized to grant the license required by this chapter for a
period not to exceed one year to any person; provided, that the applicant shall
first pay a fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) cash for the period of time
covered by such license. All such licenses issued shall be renewable upon the
expiration of the period of time for which they are issued upon payment of a
renewal fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a like period of time.
(Ord. 8311/76. Passed 4-12-76.)
   707.07  REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Mayor may revoke the license of any licensee under the terms of this
chapter who is found guilty of violating any of the provisions hereof. Any
person whose license is revoked shall not be issued another license before the
expiration of one year from the date of revocation.
(1963 Code §707.07)
   707.08  CAPPERS, BOOSTERS PROHIBITED.
   No person shall act as a by-bidder or what is commonly known as a "capper"
or "booster" at any auction sale or place, or offer or make any false bid or
offer any false bid to buy or pretend to buy any such article sold or offered
for sale at any such auction sales.
(1963 Code §707.10)
   707.09  FALSE STATEMENTS OR MISREPRESENTATIONS.
   No licensee, his agents or employees shall make any statements which are
false in any particular or which have a tendency to mislead or make any
misrepresentations whatsoever with reference to any article sold or offered for
sale during the auction.
   If any licensee, his agents or employees makes any such false statements or
misrepresentations, or hires or permits false bidders for the purpose of
encouraging other bids, the Mayor may revoke such license.
(1963 Code §707.11)
   707.10  MERCHANDISE TO BE SOLD BY PIECES, SETS OR LOTS.
   All goods, wares and merchandise to be sold at auction, as provided by this
chapter, shall be sold by individual pieces except where certain pieces of
articles constitute a set or lot, in which case they may be sold as such,
respectively.
(Ord. 8432/77. Passed 2-28-77.)
   707.11  EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to an officer or person
executing a process or order of any court having jurisdiction within the State
for selling property directed by law or court order or legal process to be sold
at public auction, nor to licensed pawnbrokers selling or offering for sale
unredeemed pledges in a manner provided by law, nor to bona fide storage
warehousemen established in the City for more than one year.
(1963 Code §707.13)
   707.12  VIOLATIONS.
   Each separate sale or offering for sale at public auction of any article of
goods, wares or merchandise in violation of the provisions hereof, shall
constitute a separate offense hereunder and shall subject the offender to the
penalty contained in
701.99 .
(Ord. 8432/77. Passed 2-28-77.)
   707.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
701.99  for general Code penalty.)

CHAPTER 713
Boxing and Wrestling
713.01   Definition.
713.02   License required. 
713.03   License application.
713.04   License issuance; fee; bond; exhibition date.
713.05   Refusal of license; appeal.
713.06   Examination of participants; fee; weighing in.
713.07   Liability insurance required.
713.08   Conduct at exhibitions.
713.09   Boxing and Wrestling Commission, creation; members.
713.10   Appointment of members; terms; compensation; vacancy.
713.11   Commission powers and duties.
713.12   Prohibited activities.
713.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Prize fighting prohibited - see Ohio R.C. 3773.08 et seq.
Public boxing exhibitions - see Ohio R.C. 3773.09
   713.01  DEFINITION.
   "Boxing and wrestling exhibition" as used in this chapter means any boxing
or wrestling match or contest to which admission may be had by payment of a fee
or by the purchase, possession or presentation of a ticket.
(1963 Code §717.01)
   713.02  LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall hold any boxing or wrestling exhibition within the limits of
the City without first obtaining a license therefor.
(1963 Code §717. 02)
   713.03  LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Every person, society or club desiring a license for holding a wrestling or
boxing exhibition shall make application to the Boxing and Wrestling Commission
therefor. Each application shall be in a form prescribed by the Commission and
shall set forth the name of the person, society or club promoting or giving
such exhibition, together with the names and addresses of the promoter, or if a
society, club, firm or corporation, the names and addresses of the two
principal officers thereof, together with statement as to the citizenship of
the promoters or officers thereof; the names and addresses of the participants
and the time and place where such exhibition is to be made.
(1963 Code §717.03)
   713.04  LICENSE ISSUANCE; FEE; BOND; EXHIBITION DATE.
   Any person, society or club conducting a boxing or wrestling exhibition as
provided for herein shall pay into the treasury of the City the sum of fifteen
dollars ($15.00) for each such exhibition. Upon payment of the fifteen dollars
($15.00) the Mayor, after receipt of the application, for such boxing or
wrestling exhibition, endorsed and approved by both the Boxing and Wrestling
Commission and the Mayor, shall issue to such applicant a license for such
exhibition. Every promoter, promoting in the City, shall deposit with the Mayor
a personal bond of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00). The Commission
shall not grant to any promoter a date for a boxing or wrestling exhibition
within forty-eight hours before, or within forty-eight hours after a date
granted to another applicant for such exhibition. However, if an applicant
insists upon a certain date to be granted, weekly or biweekly throughout the
year, the option shall rest with the Commission as to whether or not the night
before such regular exhibition shall be held vacant.
(Ord. 5503/59. Passed 6-15-59.)
   713.05  REFUSAL OF LICENSE; APPEAL.
   In the event the application for a license under the provisions of Section
713.03  is refused by the Boxing and Wrestling Commission, the Mayor shall have
authority to grant such license on appeal to him by the applicant.
(1963 Code §717.05)
   713.06  EXAMINATION OF PARTICIPANTS; FEE; WEIGHING IN.
   A properly licensed physician must examine all participants prior to taking
part in any boxing or wrestling exhibition. Either the physician appointed to
the Boxing and Wrestling Commission, or in case no such appointment is made to
the Commission, or such physician is unable to attend, any physician approved
by the Boxing and Wrestling Commission must examine all participants prior to
taking part in any boxing or wrestling exhibition. The fee for such examination
shall be two dollars ($2.00) and shall be paid by the promoter or applicant
having the license for such boxing and wrestling exhibition. In any event,
where contestants are to make a required weight by contract, or in all
professional championship bouts, participants must be weighed in by the
examining physician not later than 3:00 p.m. in the afternoon of the day of the
exhibition. All contestants in amateur wrestling and boxing exhibitions must be
weighed in prior to such exhibition. The margin of such weight and the time of
weighing shall be determined by the rules of the Boxing and Wrestling
Commission.
(1963 Code §717.06)
   713.07  LIABILITY INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   A liability insurance to protect the patrons of shows shall be carried by
promoters or owners of buildings wherein such exhibitions are given.
(1963 Code § 717.07)
   713.08  CONDUCT AT EXHIBITIONS.
   Whoever conducts themselves in or about a building or place during the time
such building or place is being used for boxing or wrestling exhibitions, in an
indecent, immoral or disorderly manner, or violates any regulation of the Fire
Marshal Act of the Ohio Revised Code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. Any
promoter of a boxing or wrestling exhibition shall be responsible for the
enforcement of the provisions of this section, and shall be held liable for any
violation thereof.
(1963 Code §717.08)
   713.09  BOXING AND WRESTLING COMMISSION; CREATION; MEMBERS.
   There is hereby created a Boxing and Wrestling Commission consisting of five
qualified electors of the City.
(1963 Code §717.09)
   713.10  APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS; TERM; COMPENSATION; VACANCY.
   The members of the Boxing and Wrestling Commission shall be appointed by the
Mayor and shall serve without compensation for a term of two years, such term
beginning not later than February 15 and running continuously for a period of
two years until such date between January 1 and February 15, as the Mayor shall
see fit to make appointment or reappointments. If for any cause a vacancy
occurs in such Commission, such vacancy shall be filled by appointment thereto
for the unexpired term.
(1963 Code §717.10)
   713.11  COMMISSION POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The duties of the Boxing and Wrestling Commission shall be to supervise all
public boxing and wrestling exhibitions to be held in the City and to make and
enforce rules not in conflict with this chapter governing the proper conduct of
such boxing and wrestling exhibitions. The members of the Commission shall have
the right to attend all boxing and wrestling exhibitions, and shall be entitled
to three passes for such exhibitions, but it shall be the duty of two members
of the Commission to be present at such exhibitions.
(1963 Code § 717.11)
   713.12  PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   No member of the Boxing and Wrestling Commission shall receive compensation
from any organization or promoter engaged in the promotion of boxing and
wrestling exhibition, nor shall any Commissioner permit his name or his
influence to be used by any one engaged in promoting such exhibitions for his
own profit.
(1963 Code §717.12)
   713.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
701.99  for general Code penalty.)

CHAPTER 717
Circuses and Carnivals
717.01   Circuses and shows.
717.02   Improper carnivals and shows.
717.03   Carnivals; license and fee.
717.04   Carnivals; license revocation.
717.05   Carnivals and shows; Council approval.
717.06   License fees generally.
717.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
Power to license and regulate shows and theatrical exhibitions - see Ohio R.C.
715.48
State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C. 1711.11(H)
Mechanical amusement devices - see BUS. REG. Ch.
729
   717.01  CIRCUSES AND SHOWS.
   No person shall exhibit within the City any circus, menagerie, horse show,
tricks of legerdemain, sideshow, exhibition of a similar nature, for which
money or any other reward, is in any manner demanded or received, without first
having a license from the Mayor.
(1963 Code §731.06)
   717.02  IMPROPER CARNIVALS AND SHOWS.
   No show, amusement device, fortuneteller or any place of entertainment or
collection of such shows, amusement devices, fortunetellers or any places of
entertainment conducted in the manner of and commonly known as a carnival,
shall exhibit to the public in the City, nor advertise a carnival nor in any
manner use the streets thereof in connection with the establishment or
exhibition of such carnival which is of a lewd, immoral, indecent or improper
character.
(1963 Code §731.07)
   717.03  CARNIVALS; LICENSE AND FEE.
   No carnival shall exhibit within the City or advertise the same within the
City without first receiving a license to do so from the Mayor for which the
Mayor shall charge a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day or any
part thereof. Licenses shall be granted for one day only, and the Mayor may in
his discretion refuse to grant a license for any succeeding day if in his
judgment such carnival is of an improper character.
(1963 Code §731.08)
   717.04  CARNIVALS; LICENSE REVOCATION.
   Any license granted by the Mayor to the exhibitors of any carnival may be
revoked at any time by the Mayor upon its being determined by him that such
carnival is not of good character as provided for in Sections
717.02  and
717.03 .
(1963 Code § 731.09)
   717.05  CARNIVALS AND SHOWS; COUNCIL APPROVAL.
   It shall be necessary for the Mayor before issuing a license for the
exhibition of a carnival or a circus, or other exhibit, as provided for in this
chapter, to secure the approval thereof from Council. Such approval shall occur
no later than one regular monthly meeting of Council prior to the event.
(Ord. 10508/93. Passed 4-28-93.)
   717.06  LICENSE FEES GENERALLY.
   The Mayor shall not issue and deliver any license provided for in Section
717.01  to any person until he has received for the use of the City the
following consideration therefor: for each circus or menagerie, not less than
ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than fifty dollars ($50.00) per day; for
sideshows, horse shows or exhibitions of similar nature, not less than three
dollars ($3.00) nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per day.
(1963 Code §731.16)
   717.99  PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
701.99  for general Code penalty.)
